notesStmt.note: Elwood Mead (1858-1936) was appointed Wyoming territorial engineer in 1888 and was Wyoming's first state engineer, serving until 1899. As such, Mead was intimately involved in the drafting and administration of Wyoming's water laws. Mead's engineering reports on the Shoshone River provided crucial backing for William F. Cody and his partners in the Cody Canal project. The "red bluffs" and Sulphur Creek lie south of Cody, along the route for the Cody-Salsbury Canal. Red Lodge, Montana, is about sixty miles north of Cody. Dennis Cunningham was one of the shareholders of the company organized on March 20, 1895, which later would be named the Shoshone Land and Irrigation Company [See Bonner "William F. Cody's Empire" pages 13,31,70,72].

div1.note:
Ralph Kitchen, Manager.
The Paxton, Omaha Neb.
div1.p:
Mead leaves Cheyenne tomorrow to go and consult with you if we ever needed his services it is right now to examine and approoveaprove of our ditch and give us an estimate on both propositions North & South side. and allsoalso help getting arroundaround or through those red bluffs1 where we take the water out of Sulphur creek.2 I would suggest that he be allowed to go over the accounts & see what the work so far has cost. The amount of lumber needed and the prospect of getting it So he can give a full report. And with his re-
Ralph Kitchen, Manager.
The Paxton, Omaha Neb.
_______ 189__
portreport I may be able to raise the money to push work through—
Will you send to Red Lodge3 for him and give him what assistance you can so as to hurry his report.

postscript.p: PS. George Dennis Cunningham has a man here who says he Knows how to put those graders together & run them. he wants $200 per day & board. if you want him write Dennis.

back.note: Note 1: Red Bluffs is a hill formation to the south and west of Cody, Wyoming, that stands out among the mountainous formations due to its red color.
Note 2: Sulphur Creek is a natural streambed located west of Cody, Wyoming, flowing north toward the Shoshone River along the base of Cedar Mountain.
Note 3: Red Lodge, Montana, lies 65 miles north of Cody and is the closest rail line to Cody, Wyoming.
